intro: Aster argillarius, commonly known as the clay aster, is a perennial herb native to the central and eastern United States. It is characterized by its hairy stems and clusters of small, lavender to blue-purple flowers that bloom in late summer. The plant typically grows in moist, clay soils and thrives in partial to full shade. Its leaves are lance-shaped and covered in fine hairs, contributing to its distinctive appearance. Aster argillarius is valued for its ornamental qualities and serves as a nectar source for pollinators.
